article.title: Efficient cold outflows driven by cosmic rays in high redshift galaxies and their global effects on the IGM

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the sudden increase in the velocity of the outflow after crossing the virial radius indicate (panel b and d)?
choices: The outflow is transitioning to a momentum-driven phase.
The inner shock is catching up with the outer shock.
The assumed gas density profile changes rapidly outside the halo.
The cosmic ray pressure has overtaken the thermal pressure.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the most significant difference between outflows from high-mass galaxies (as shown in Figure 3) and low-mass galaxies (as shown in Figure 2)?
choices: The maximum velocity achieved by the outflow.
The final physical radius of the outflow.
The amount of metals ejected into the IGM.
The temperature evolution of the outflowing material.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key implication can be derived from Equation 20 concerning the IGM?
choices: Cosmic rays cannot efficiently transfer energy to the thermal gas in the IGM.
Cosmic rays could heat the IGM to observed temperatures if magnetic fields are sufficiently strong.
The Hubble time is too short for cosmic rays to significantly impact the IGM temperature.
The pressure gradient scale of IGM filaments is too large for cosmic ray heating to be effective.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference in the volume filling factor predicted by the Sheth-Tormen (ST) mass function compared to the Press-Schechter (PS) mass function?
choices: The ST mass function predicts a significantly larger volume filling factor, particularly at lower redshifts.
The PS mass function predicts a more rapid increase in the volume filling factor at early epochs.
Both mass functions result in similar volume filling factors at z=0.
The choice of mass function has negligible impact on the volume filling factor.
